items.text:
The biggest arbitrage in lead gen right now isn't cold email or cold calling.

It's WhatsApp.

2B+ people use it daily.

And almost nobody in the agency worldis paying attention.

2 billion people use it every single day.

Not as a "nice-to-have."

As THE way they do business.

In Dubai, your dentist confirms appointments on WhatsApp.
In S√£o Paulo, your lawyer sends contracts on WhatsApp.
In London, your estate agent closes deals on WhatsApp.

And in the US‚Ä¶

We're still sending "Just checking in!" emails
that get opened by exactly... nobody.

Let's look at the numbers for a second:

Cold email open rate: 22%
SMS open rate: 45%
WhatsApp open rate: 98%

Ninety. Eight. Percent.

And yet most agencies are over here
A/B testing email subject lines
like that's going to close a 76-point gap.

Here's where it gets interesting though.

WhatsApp Business API now supports
rich media, automation, and full CRM integration.

Pair that with Voice AI and things get wild:

‚Üí AI agents call back within 60 seconds of a WhatsApp inquiry
‚Üí They run 24/7 across every time zone
‚Üí No sick days. No hold music. No "let me transfer you."

MIT research says responding within 5 minutes
makes you 100x more likely to convert.

We're talking 60 seconds.

No call center on earth can staff that.

When your agency can deliver this to clients,
you're not just adding another service.

You're entering markets where WhatsApp
isn't optional but DEFAULT.

Europe. Middle East. LATAM. Southeast Asia.

That's not a feature add.
That's an entire continent of pipeline
most agencies don't even know exists.

The cool thing is this is exactly what we built Wave Runner for.

Native WhatsApp integration.
Realistic Voice AI.
Native CRM Integrations with GHL & Hubspot.
Native workflow builder.
White-label ready.

All in one place.

If you run an agency or BPO
and haven't explored WhatsApp + Voice AI yet

you're not behind the curve.

You're on a different road entirely.

Drop a üåç if you want me to break down
exactly how the system works.

I made the YC application GUIDE I wish I‚Äôd had when I was applying üî•
YC accepts ~1.5% of founders - most applications fail for the same reasons:

After reviewing 100+ YC applications, I kept seeing the same mistakes - even from strong founders with good ideas.

It took me 3 tries to get into Y Combinator with Fluently: AI English tutor, GetFluently.app (YC W24) because I made those mistakes myself. That's why I decided to put together a guide to help founders apply the right way from the start.

What‚Äôs inside:
- How to answer YC questions
- Real examples from successful applications
- The most common mistakes that quietly kill applications
- How to show progress, traction, and founder-market fit (even if you‚Äôre early)

This guide is based on my personal experience and was reviewed by other YC alumni and partners. So check it out before applying!

--
üìå Save this & send it to a founder who‚Äôs preparing their YC application

Voice isn‚Äôt a feature. It‚Äôs the default.

We just shipped ClawdTalk.

Your Clawdbot now has a real phone number.
Same agent. Same tools. Same memory.
You just call it and talk.

If you‚Äôve ever thought, ‚Äúthis would be easier if I could just call it‚Äù
you were right.

I spent 50+ hours building apps with AI.

This 5-step framework saved me from wasting 90% of that time:

Most people jump into AI tools and start prompting randomly.

No plan. No structure. No idea what "done" looks like.

That's why 80% of AI projects stall after day one.

I built the BLAST framework to fix that.

It works for any AI coding tool. Any project. Any skill level.

Here's the breakdown:

B ‚Üí Blueprint your outcome before you touch a tool
L ‚Üí Link your integrations (APIs, databases, services)
A ‚Üí Architect the plan (let AI map it, you approve it)
S ‚Üí Style the experience (UI, brand, user flow)
T ‚Üí Trigger the execution (schedule it, ship it, automate it)

I've used this to build 12 live applications.

3 of them generate revenue on autopilot.

The difference between people who build cool demos and people who ship real products?

A system. Not motivation.

I turned BLAST into a free one-pager you can use on every project.

Comment "BLAST" and I'll send it over.

ü§Øü§Øü§Ø OPUS 4.6 ‚Üí iOS mobile app

My scrappy, bootstrapped vibe coding tool ($7k MRR) is up there with the billion-dollar companies

Lovable: $6.6B valuation, $300M ARR
Replit: $3B valuation, $250M ARR
Base44: probably $20-30M+ ARR

Scrappy us: $0 raised, $7k MRR

Things we have that they don't:
‚Ä¢ Build Chrome Extensions
‚Ä¢ We help you publish them easily
‚Ä¢ Build mobile apps: iOS and Android (almost live)
‚Ä¢ WE make it painless to publish on the App Stores
‚Ä¢ Go multi-language with your app, 80+ languages, 1 click
‚Ä¢ Animated background videos
‚Ä¢ SOON: Email sending to your app/website's users
‚Ä¢ SOON: email sequences, e.g. you tell Shipper "build a welcome sequence flow for new users" ‚Üí this'll be a game changer
++ Much much more... on a fraction of the budget

Anthropic just shipped Agent Teams into Claude Code and I put together a complete guide on how to install and use them.

The OpenClaw community was already doing this with custom skills and workarounds....

Anthropic noticed and made it native.

No plugins or setup hacks needed.

It's built right into the tool now.

Instead of one agent doing everything solo in a straight line, a lead agent now breaks your task into pieces, spins up multiple teammates, and they all work on different parts of your project at the same time.

One researches, one debugs, one builds.

They talk to each other, share findings, and coordinate through a shared task list without you having to manage any of it.

The guide covers:
‚Üí What agent teams are and how they actually work
‚Üí How they're different from sub-agents (and when to use which)
‚Üí How to enable them in your settings in 30 seconds
‚Üí How to start your first team and what to say
‚Üí Best practices so you don't burn through tokens
‚Üí The limitations you need to know before you start

This is one of those features that sounds small on paper but completely changes how you work with Claude Code once you start using it.
